title: 115_s863
content: The Offshoring Prevention Act, also known as the Act, focuses on the taxation of income of controlled foreign corporations related to imported property. The Offshoring Prevention Act focuses on the taxation of imported property income derived from manufacturing, producing, growing, or extracting imported property. The Offshoring Prevention Act focuses on taxing income from imported property, including sales, exchanges, dispositions, leases, rentals, or licenses of imported property. Imported property refers to items brought into the US by a controlled foreign corporation or related person. The term 'imported property' includes property brought into the US by an unrelated person, with expectations of it being imported or used in other imported goods. The term 'imported property' refers to property brought into the US by a controlled foreign corporation or related person for use outside the US or as a component in other property sold outside the US. Agricultural commodities not grown in commercially marketable quantities in the US are excluded from this definition. Definitions and special rules for the import of property into the United States include the definition of 'import' as entering or withdrawing from warehouse for consumption, the inclusion of intangible property rights, and the definition of 'United States' to include various territories. The term 'unrelated person' is defined as someone not related to the entity in question. The text discusses the exclusion of imported property income from foreign base company sales income for tax purposes. It also addresses the separate application of limitations on foreign tax credit for imported property income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude imported property income from foreign base company sales income for tax purposes. Additionally, limitations on foreign tax credit for imported property income are separately addressed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude imported property income from foreign base company sales income for tax purposes. The amendments also address limitations on foreign tax credit for imported property income. These changes apply to taxable years of foreign corporations beginning after the enactment of the Act, and to taxable years of United States. The amendments apply to taxable years of foreign corporations beginning after the enactment of this Act, and to taxable years of United States shareholders within which or with which such taxable years of such foreign corporations end.
